Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Investigations on Hydrodynamic and Diffusional-thermal Flamefront Instabilities

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1510142 (Law)

The project aims to better understand how burning of fuel-air mixture takes place under high-pressure and very turbulent conditions, similar to those in an engine. The Principal Investigator has recently developed an experimental method that enables obtaining data with very high resolutions that was not previously available. The data can help explain the behavior of combustion and potentially help design energy-efficient combustion devices. Both graduate and undergraduate students will be involved in the proposed research and the knowledge gained will be published and taught in the classroom.

The proposed study is aim to differentiating the effects due to hydrodynamic and diffusive-thermal instabilities, especially under high pressures (60-80 atmospheres). Because of the reduced flame thickness with increasing pressure, hydrodynamic instability is relevant to high-pressure reciprocating and gas turbine combustion engines. The interest to increase the compression ratio and thereby combustion efficiency of these engines further accentuates the preponderance of the hydrodynamics instability. The PI designs the laminar flame conditions for investigation, but these conditions will impact, with possible revisions to, the classical turbulent premixed regime diagram. Newly developed diagnostic tools with high temporal and spatial resolutions will help to obtain high-quality data that allows validations of the proposed hypothesis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This three-year research program studied the propagation and acceleration of flames in the presence of the intrinsic cellular flamefront instabilities, for the understanding and modeling of combustion processes especially those in high-pressure environments. The investigation involved experimentation on spherical flames under high- and constant-pressure conditions, aiming to acquire experimental data of high fidelity in order to quantitatively define the various stability parameters and boundaries of the instability modes. Consequently, the major goals of the projects were to determine the flame self-acceleration rate as functions of the physics-controlling parameters, such as the Peclet number, thermal expansion ratio, and Lewis number; and to determine the effect of such instabilities on the propagation of turbulent flames. Below we discuss three key outcomes of the program in the lights of Intellectual Merits and Broader Impacts.

Intellectual Merits

The investigation on the development and self-acceleration of Darrieus-Landau vs diffusional-thermal instabilities showed that irrespective of pressure and flame temperature, it is possible to unify the normalized flame speed data by plotting them against the Peclet number at various pressures. We further demonstrated three stages: smooth, transitional and saturated, of flame propagation with pure hydrodynamic instability (Le~1 and Le>1 mixtures). For Le<1 mixtures, diffusional thermal instability was seen to enhance flame propagation through additional cells. In a separate study we investigated the role of preferential diffusion on the propagation of turbulent flames for moderate to high turbulence intensities. Using a weakly burning mixture which is near the flammability limit, we demonstrated that for Le<1 mixtures the propagation can be significantly enhanced in the presence of turbulence. This is achieved through the strong burning of positively wrinkled flame segments compared to the weakly stretched segments for Le<1 mixtures. Stronger turbulence intensities, however, reduce the overall burning speed due to local extinction as prominent finger like structures emerge.  We furthermore studied turbulent flames, particularly, to understand the interaction between the cellular flame-front instability and turbulence in flame propagation. Through scaling analysis, corroborated by extensive experiments conducted at atmospheric and elevated (upto 25 atm) pressure conditions using both diffusionally stable (Le=1) and unstable (Le<1) mixtures, we found that cellular instability dominates flame acceleration in the Wrinkled Flamelet Regime of the Borghi diagram and turbulence dominates in the Thickened Flamelet Regime, while they interact with each other and both influence flame propagation in the Corrugated Flamelet Regime.

Broader Impact

Flame front instability is unavoidable in high-pressure flames, specifically in practical applications, such as those within internal combustion reciprocating engines and gas turbines. To model the burning characteristics in these complex high-pressure systems, in which the interplay of turbulence, instability and chemistry are omnipresent, fundamental understanding of each of the building blocks is critical. Our study suggests that the cellularly unstable expanding flame, even in the absence of turbulence, can accelerate almost at a fixed rate irrespective of the pressure, Lewis number and flame temperature. Such knowledge is useful in developing reduced-order models for simulations.

The extreme augmentation of flame propagation in turbulence through preferential diffusion is a pivotal result for turbulent combustion, in which we show the pertaining influence of molecular diffusivity even at high turbulent Reynolds numbers. Moreover, by achieving high burning speeds for a mixture with adiabatic temperature lower than 900K, we have “extended” the flammability limit, suggesting that practical engines can actually operate in extremely lean condition, leading to substantially reduced emission.

Determination of the role of flamefront instability on turbulent flame is an important and realistic problem in high-pressure turbulent combustors, such as IC engines and gas turbines. Our results provide a scaling analysis of cellular instability and turbulence interaction and identify a regime diagram. Also, we show that diffusional-thermal instability increases the total burning rate of turbulent expanding flames but does not change the flame acceleration rate. These results are useful in understanding the basic physics of turbulent combustion with flame front instability and developing new models for simulations such as the flame surface density model.

Modified by: Chung K Law
